importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the upcoming parliamentary elections in the Netherlands, where AI-generated voting advice is being scrutinized for its potential to distort voter choices.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the Dutch Data Protection Authority conducted tests on AI chatbots and issued public warnings about their use in voting decisions ahead of the election.

keyTakeAways: AI chatbots such as ChatGPT, Gemini, Mistral, and Grok provide biased, distorted, and polarized political advice when used to determine voting preferences.
In tests involving 1,500 fictitious voter profiles, AI models frequently recommended fringe parties like the Party for Freedom (PVV) and Green Left-Labour Party as top choices.

Centrally positioned parties such as Democrats 66 and People’s Party for Freedom and Democracy were recommended far less often, and some parties like Christian Democratic Appeal and Denk were almost never suggested.
The Dutch Data Protection Authority warns that using AI for voting decisions undermines democratic integrity due to lack of transparency and verifiability.
The watchdog urges both voters and chatbot providers to avoid using AI as a voting guide to preserve the fairness and authenticity of elections.

The upcoming election follows political instability caused by the Party for Freedom's withdrawal from coalition talks over immigration policy, heightening concerns about voter misinformation and polarization.

namedEntities.name: Dutch Data Protection Authority
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A national regulatory body in the Netherlands responsible for overseeing data privacy and protecting individual rights.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dutch Data Protection Authority is the primary entity issuing a public warning against using AI chatbots for voting advice, highlighting concerns about bias and lack of transparency in AI-generated political recommendations.

namedEntities.name: ChatGPT
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A popular artificial intelligence language model developed by OpenAI.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ChatGPT was tested in the study and was found to provide distorted and polarized political advice, making it a key example of AI systems that may mislead voters.

namedEntities.name: Gemini
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An AI language model developed by Google.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Gemini was included in the tests and showed a strong tendency to recommend extreme political parties, illustrating AI’s potential to amplify political polarization.

namedEntities.name: Mistral
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An AI language model developed by Mistral AI.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mistral was tested and found to similarly recommend fringe parties, showing that multiple major AI platforms produce unreliable political recommendations.

namedEntities.name: Grok
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An AI chatbot developed by xAI, Elon Musk’s company.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Grok was included in the study and exhibited biased tendencies in political recommendations, reinforcing concerns about AI’s role in shaping voter perception.

namedEntities.name: Party for Freedom (PVV)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A hard-right political party in the Netherlands, led by Geert Wilders, known for its anti-immigration stance.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The PVV is a frequently recommended party by AI chatbots, raising concerns about misinformation and the influence of AI on voter choices in a major election.

namedEntities.name: Green Left-Labour Party
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A left-wing political party in the Netherlands, representing progressive and environmental policies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This party was also frequently recommended by AI models, indicating that AI tends to favor politically extreme or fringe options over moderate parties.

namedEntities.name: People’s Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A right-leaning political party in the Netherlands, traditionally aligned with conservative and centrist policies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This party was recommended less often by AI models, suggesting that AI algorithms are systematically underrepresenting centrist political options.

namedEntities.name: Democrats 66 (D66)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A centre-left political party in the Netherlands, known for its progressive and liberal policies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: D66 was significantly underrepresented in AI recommendations, highlighting the lack of balanced political advice from AI systems.

namedEntities.name: Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A conservative Christian political party in the Netherlands, often positioned on the centre-right.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CDA was almost never recommended by AI chatbots, indicating a potential bias in AI models toward more extreme political positions.

namedEntities.name: Denk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A left-leaning political party in the Netherlands, representing progressive and socially active values.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Denk was almost never suggested by AI models, showing that AI-generated political advice is skewed and fails to reflect a full spectrum of political options.

namedEntities.name: Geert Wilders
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A prominent Dutch political figure and leader of the Party for Freedom (PVV), known for his anti-immigration rhetoric.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Wilders led the PVV, which is a key party in the current political climate and a frequent AI recommendation, contributing to concerns about AI-driven voter bias.

namedEntities.name: October 29, 2025
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The date of the Dutch parliamentary elections.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The timing of the election is central to the context, as the AI testing and warnings were issued in anticipation of this vote.

namedEntities.name: Immigration policy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key political issue in the Netherlands, particularly in relation to the Party for Freedom’s platform.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The political crisis involving the PVV's withdrawal from coalition talks over immigration policy sets the stage for a contested election and amplifies concerns about AI misinformation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Dutch Data Protection Authority has issued a public warning against using AI chatbots such as ChatGPT, Gemini, Mistral, and Grok to decide how to vote, citing extensive testing that revealed these models frequently recommend extreme political parties—such as the hard-right Party for Freedom (PVV) and the left-wing Green Left-Labour Party—while largely ignoring centrist parties like Democrats 66 and the People’s Party for Freedom and Democracy. The watchdog emphasizes that AI systems provide biased, distorted, and unverifiable advice due to lack of transparency, and warns that such use undermines the integrity of democratic elections. This comes at a critical time as the Netherlands prepares for parliamentary elections on October 29, following political instability caused by the PVV’s refusal to support a coalition over immigration policy. The article underscores the growing risks of AI influencing political decisions and calls on both voters and AI developers to avoid using these tools for voting guidance.
title: Don’t ask AI for advice on how to vote, Dutch watchdog warns
